THE NEW JERSEY DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION PLANS TO RESTORE 193 ACRES OF NATIVE HABITAT AT THE MAD HORSE CREEK WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREA IN LOWER ALLOWAYS TOWNSHIP, SALEM COUNTY, NEW JERSEY.  THE PROJECT WILL CONSIST OF EXCAVATION ALONG THE EXISTING SALT MARSH TO RESTORE TIDAL CHANNELS AND ELIMINATE THE INVASIVE COMMON REED (PHRAGMITES AUSTRALIS). APPROXIMATELY 59 ACRES OF NATIVE SALT MARSH WILL BE PLANTED, EDGED BY ABOUT 5 ACRES OF NATIVE HIGH MARSH AND ABOUT 3.5 ACRES OF NATIVE TIDAL SCRUB-SHRUB HABITAT. A NEW BRIDGE WILL BE BUILT OVER ONE OF THE NEW TIDAL CHANNELS TO ALLOW ACCESS TO AN EXISTING BOAT RAMP. THE FORMER AGRICULTURAL FIELDS ON THE PROPERTY WILL BE RESTORED TO ABOUT 40 ACRES OF NATIVE FRESHWATER WETLANDS AND 90 ACRES OF UPLAND COASTAL GRASSLANDS.  THE PROJECT SITE IS LOCATED IN A KEY LOCATION IN THE ATLANTIC FLYWAY, A GLOBALLY SIGNIFICANT STOPOVER SITE FOR MIGRATORY SHOREBIRDS, WATERBIRDS, RAPTORS, AND NEOTROPICAL BIRDS.  THE FINISHED PROJECT WILL IMPROVE HABITAT FOR MIGRATORY BIRD SPECIES, AND PROVIDE ENHANCED NESTING HABITAT FOR AT-RISK MARSH SPECIES SUCH AS THE SALTMARSH SPARROW AND BLACK RAIL.  THE PROJECT SITE IS ALSO WITHIN THE DELAWARE ESTUARY AND IS DESIGNATED AS ESSENTIAL FISH HABITAT BY NOAA. THE RESTORED TIDAL MARSH HYDROLOGY AND HABITAT WILL BENEFIT ANADRAMOUS AND NATIVE FISH SPECIES.  THE RESTORATION IS EXPECTED TO BEGIN IN 2023, AND TAKE APPROXIMATELY 2 YEARS TO COMPLETE.  THE SITE WILL BE MONITORED POST-RESTORATION TO ENSURE PROJECT SUCCESS.  LONG-TERM MAINTENANCE OF THE PROJECT SITE WILL BE THE RESPONSIBILITY OF THE DIVISION OF FISH   WILDLIFE, WHICH MANAGES NEW JERSEY S WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS.  PLEASE SEE THE ATTACHED PROJECT NARRATIVE FOR ADDITIONAL INFORMATION.

THE PROJECT WILL RESTORE  14.3 ACRES OF COASTAL WETLANDS AND ASSOCIATED UPLANDS IN THE BIG CANYON NATURE PARK IN UPPER NEWPORT BAY IN THE CITY OF NEWPORT BEACH. THIS IS THE FINAL PHASE OF A MULTI-PHASE WATER QUALITY, HABITAT RESTORATION, AND CLIMATE ADAPTATION PROJECT IN THE BIG CANYON NATURE PARK, AND WILL RESTORE A SELF-SUSTAINING COASTAL WETLANDS COMPLEX ACROSS THE TIDAL TO FRESHWATER TO UPLANDS CONTINUUM. THE PROJECT WILL RESTORE AND ENHANCE  1,900 FT OF TIDAL AND CREEK CHANNEL, 2.8 AC OF TIDAL MARSH, 7.3 AC OF TRANSITIONAL WETLANDS, AND 4.2 AC OF COASTAL SAGE SCRUB. THE PROJECT INVOLVES GRADING TO EXTEND TIDAL INFLUENCE AND RESTORE TIDAL MARSH, TRANSITION ZONE WETLANDS, AND RIPARIAN HABITAT  REMOVAL OF AN ARTIFICIAL BERM  RESTORATION OF THE MOUTH OF BIG CANYON CREEK  REMOVAL OF INVASIVE PLANTS FOCUSED ON BRAZILIAN PEPPERTREES  AND SOIL PLACEMENT AND PLANTING TO RESTORE COASTAL SAGE SCRUB ADJACENT TO THE WETLANDS. GRADING WILL RESTORE TIDAL SALT MARSH HABITAT BY EXTENDING TIDAL INFLUENCE AND REDIRECTING DRY WEATHER URBAN FLOWS AWAY FROM THE MARSH. AN ARTIFICIAL BERM IN THE PROJECT AREA IS CURRENTLY PONDING WATER AND HAS LED TO THE DEVELOPMENT OF A MONOCULTURAL CATTAIL MARSH. BERM REMOVAL, INVASIVES REMOVAL, GRADING, AND PLANTING WILL RESTORE CREEK CHANNEL, RIPARIAN SCRUB, AND TRANSITIONAL FRESHWATER WETLANDS TO THE CATTAIL POND AREA. THE PROJECT WILL ESTABLISH A RIPARIAN CORRIDOR THAT INTEGRATES WITH THE UPSTREAM RESTORED CORRIDOR FROM PHASES 1 AND 2 OF THE BIG CANYON RESTORATION. THE RESTORED CHANNEL WILL MAINTAIN POSITIVE DRAINAGE DURING LOW FLOWS, CONVEYING DRY WEATHER FLOWS AWAY FROM THE RESTORED INTERTIDAL SALT MARSH TO MAINTAIN THE SALINITY REQUIRED TO SUPPORT SALT MARSH VEGETATION. STORM FLOWS WILL STILL INUNDATE THE FULL MARSH PLAIN TO MAINTAIN THE FULL EXTENT OF THE RESTORED WETLANDS AND RESTORE NATURAL HYDROLOGY. RESTORED HYDROLOGY AND WETLANDS WILL REDUCE THE SELENIUM ACCUMULATION IN SOIL AND VEGETATION AND REDUCE MOSQUITO BREEDING HABITAT BY CONVERTING THE CATTAIL MONOCULTURE TO RIPARIAN AND TRANSITIONAL FRESHWATER HABITAT. THE PROJECT ALSO INVOLVES RESTORATION OF COASTAL SAGE SCRUB ADJACENT TO THE RIPARIAN AND TRANSITION WETLANDS. RESTORED HABITATS AND IMPROVED WATER QUALITY WILL BENEFIT LISTED SPECIES, INCLUDING LEAST BELL S VIREO, CALIFORNIA GNATCATCHER, LIGHT-FOOTED RIDGWAY S RAIL, BELDING S SAVANNAH SPARROW, SALT MARSH BIRD S BEAK, AND CALIFORNIA LEAST TERN. THE PROJECT ALSO INCLUDES EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMING AND IMPROVED PUBLIC ACCESS. BIG CANYON CREEK IS IN URGENT NEED OF HABITAT RESTORATION TO ADDRESS WATER QUALITY AND HABITAT DEGRADATION DUE TO DREDGE AND FILL MATERIALS PLACED WITHIN THE LOWER CANYON MARSH PLAIN AND RIPARIAN AREAS, UPSTREAM DEVELOPMENT, SELENIUM-LADEN GROUNDWATER SEEPAGE, HISTORICAL GRAZING AND AGRICULTURE, INCREASED PEAK-FLOWS DURING STORM EVENTS AND YEAR-ROUND DRY WEATHER FLOWS DUE TO URBANIZATION, AND INVASIVE PLANTS AND INSECTS. WITHOUT RESTORATION, ANY REMAINING NATIVE HABITATS WILL RAPIDLY DISAPPEAR FROM THIS IMPORTANT COASTAL TRIBUTARY OF UPPER NEWPORT BAY, AND THERE WILL BE INCREASED IMPACTS FROM POOR WATER QUALITY AND FUTURE SEA LEVEL RISE.PROJECT CONSTRUCTION IS ANTICIPATED TO BEGIN IN FALL 2023 WITH SUBSTANTIAL COMPLETION BY FALL 2024, FOLLOWED BY A FIVE-YEAR PLANT AND HABITAT ESTABLISHMENT AND MAINTENANCE PERIOD. THE PROJECT IS LED BY THE NEWPORT BAY CONSERVANCY (NBC) IN COLLABORATION WITH CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE AND THE CITY OF NEWPORT BEACH. NBC HAS SUCCESSFULLY COMPLETED PHASE 2 (NCWC FUNDED) AND COLLABORATED WITH THE CITY ON THE SUCCESSFUL COMPLETION OF PHASE 1. THE MAJORITY OF THE PROJECT SITE IS A PART OF THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE S UPPER NEWPORT BAY ECOLOGICAL RESERVE.

THE CALIFORNIA COASTAL CONSERVANCY, CALIFORNIA TROUT, INC., AND THE YUROK TRIBE ARE RECEIVING  1,000,000 FROM THENATIONAL COASTAL WETLAND CONSERVATION GRANT PROGRAM TO IMPLEMENT PHASE 3B OF THE PRAIRIE CREEK FLOODPLAINRESTORATION PROJECT (PCFRP). THE PROJECT IS LOCATED ON A FORMER MILL SITE NORTH OR ORICK IN HUMBOLDT COUNTY,CALIFORNIA.REDWOOD CREEK AND ITS TRIBUTARY PRAIRIE CREEK ARE CRITICAL HABITAT FOR SONCC COHO SALMON, CC CHINOOK SALMON, AND NC STEELHEAD. THE REDWOOD CREEK COHO POPULATION IS DEEMED  CORE  TO SPECIES RECOVERY AND THE CREEK S POPULATIONS OF CHINOOK AND STEELHEAD ARE  ESSENTIAL  TO RECOVERY.PRAIRIE CREEK, UPSTREAM OF ITS CONFLUENCE WITH REDWOOD CREEK ABOUT 3 MILES FROM THE COAST, PROVIDES SOME OF THE HIGHEST QUALITY SALMONID HABITAT ON THE NORTH COAST OF CALIFORNIA. DOWNSTREAM OF THE CONFLUENCE, HOWEVER, THE LAST THREE MILES OF REDWOOD CREEK ARE CONFINED BY LEVEES AND ONLY SMALL REMNANTS OF ESTUARINE HABITAT REMAIN AT THE COAST. THE DEGRADED ESTUARY AND LACK OF FLOODPLAIN CONNECTIVITY NEAR THE COAST SIGNIFICANTLY REDUCES THE PRODUCTIVITY OF SALMONIDS IN A WATERSHED OF EXCEPTIONAL POTENTIAL, AND ARE IDENTIFIED AS KEY LIMITING STRESSES INRECOVERY PLANS FOR THE CREEK.THE PCFRP WILL RESTORE THE LIMITED REARING AND SPAWNING HABITAT NEEDED FOR RECOVERY OF LISTED SALMONIDS ANDSUPPORT PACIFIC SALMON FISHERIES. THE PCFRP WILL IMPROVE 0.9 MILES OF INSTREAM HABITAT, RESTORE ACCESS TO NEARLY23 ACRES OF FLOODPLAIN AND BACKWATER HABITAT, AND RESTORE OR CONSERVE UP TO 19 ACRES OF EMERGENT WETLAND ANDNEARLY 24 ACRES OF RIPARIAN VEGETATION.PHASE 3B HAS A FOOTPRINT OF 44.26 ACRES AND WILL ACHIEVE THE FOLLOWING OBJECTIVES BY 12-31-26:1: INSTALL ONE 2-ACRE FRESHWATER EMERGENT BACKWATER POND.2: MODIFY 1,676 FEET OF STREAMBANK BY LAYING BACK THE SLOPE.3: INSTALL 5 LARGE WOOD STRUCTURES IN NEWLY EXCAVATED SECTION OF PRAIRIE CREEK AND THE NEW POND.4: REMOVE 5.8 ACRES OF INVASIVE PLANTS AND REVEGETATE 6.6 ACRES OF WETLAND, RIPARIAN, AND UPLAND HABITAT.5. INSTALL TEMPORARY EXCLUSIONARY FENCING TO PROTECT NEW VEGETATION.6. REMOVE ONE 6-ACRE AREA OF FORMER MILL SITE ASPHALT TO PROVIDE FOR FILL STORAGE FOR SUCCESSIVE RESTORATIONPHASES.7: DEVELOP AND POST 10 DIGITAL PRODUCTS FEATURING THE RESTORATION PROJECT.8: SPONSOR 6 GUIDED BIRDING EVENTS AT THE SITE AND 3 SITE TOURS.THE PCFRP IS A COMPONENT OF A LARGER INITIATIVE KNOWN AS THE REDWOOD NATIONAL AND STATE PARK VISITOR CENTER AND RESTORATION PROJECT (RNSPVCR PROJECT), WHICH INVOLVES CONSTRUCTION OF A WORLD-CLASS VISITOR CENTER NEXT TO THE RESTORED CREEK. THE PROJECT PROPERTY IS LOCATED JUST OUTSIDE OF THE RNSP AND OWNED BY SAVE THE REDWOODS LEAGUE, BUT WHEN THE RESTORATION IS COMPLETE WILL BE TRANSFERRED TO THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE FOR INCLUSION IN THE RNSP.OUTCOMES BENEFICIARIES:-19.32 ACRES OF NATIONALLY DECLINING PALUSTRINE WETLANDS WILL BE RESTORED NEAR THE COAST TO HELP PROVIDE MISSINGREARING HABITAT AND IMPROVE DOWNSTREAM BASEFLOWS.-THE RECOVERY OF FEDERALLY THREATENED SONCC COHO AND CC CHINOOK SALMON, AND NC STEELHEAD WILL BE SUPPORTED.-HABITAT FOR 23 FEDERALLY OR STATE LISTED SPECIES OR STATE SPECIES OF SPECIAL CONCERN WILL BE ENHANCED.-WATER QUALITY WILL BE IMPROVED IN ESSENTIAL FISH HABITAT BY THE PROJECT S REMOVAL OF ASPHALT AND ITSCONTAMINANTS AND INVASIVE PLANTS.-THE COMMUNITY WILL BE ENGAGED WITH THE PROJECT THROUGH EMPLOYMENT, ONSITE TOURS, BIRDING EVENTS, AND SOCIALMEDIA REPORTS AND UPDATES.-FUTURE RESTORATION OF DECLINING WETLANDS IN THE REDWOOD CREEK ESTUARY WILL BE CATALYZED BY THE LARGER RNSPVCR PROJECT, AS IT WILL FACILITATE REMOVAL OF THE OLD VISITOR CENTER IN THE ESTUARY-THE PROJECT WILL SERVE AS A LIVING DEMONSTRATION OF SALMONID HABITAT NEEDS WHEN THE RESTORED HABITAT IS ONDISPLAY AT THE NEW RNSP VISITOR CENTER.-LOCAL ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITIES FOR DISADVANTAGED COMMUNITIES WILL BE EXPANDED BY THE PROJECT AND THE FUTUREVISITOR CENTER OF WHICH IT IS A PART.-THE YUROK TRIBE WILL HAVE MEANINGFUL ROLES IN THE PROJECT.

THE CALIFORNIA STATE COASTAL CONSERVANCY AND CENTRAL COAST WETLANDS GROUP ARE REQUESTING  1,000,000 TO COMPLETE PHASE I OF THE CASTROVILLE TO THE COAST PROJECT, ACQUIRING 24 ACRES OF PROPERTY FOR FUTURE FLOODPLAIN RESTORATION. THE PROJECT WILL ENGAGE WITH THREE PRIVATE AGRICULTURAL LANDOWNERS WHO OWN THE 40 ACRES NECESSARY TO COMPLETE THE MULTI PHASES PROJECT, DRAFTING EASEMENT LANGUAGE ACCEPTABLE TO ALL THREE LANDOWNERS, AND ACQUIRE 24 ACRES FROM ONE LANDOWNER (OCEAN MIST FARMS). THE REMAINING 16 ACRES CAN BE ACQUIRED IN FUTURE PROJECT PHASES. INITIAL PROJECT DESIGNS FOR THE FULL 40 ACRES PROJECT (30  ENGINEERING DESIGNS) WILL BE COMPLETED BY THE TIME OF GRANT EXECUTION AND ADDITIONAL PROJECT PLANNING IS ANTICIPATED TO OCCUR CONCURRENTLY WITH PHASE I ACQUISITION.THE SALINAS RECLAMATION DITCH TEMBLADERO SLOUGH WAS CONSTRUCTED IN 1906 TO  RECLAIM  LAKES AND FLOOD LANDS OF THE LOWER SALINAS VALLEY FOR ROW CROP AGRICULTURE AT A TIME WHEN STORMWATER DISCHARGES FROM URBAN AND AGRICULTURE DRAINAGE AREAS WERE FAR LESS THAN TODAY. IN 1998, MONTEREY COUNTY WATER RESOURCES AGENCY INITIATED A STUDY TO ADDRESS RECENT FLOODING WITHIN THE LOWER SALINAS VALLEY WHICH WAS NO LONGER SERVED BY THE ANTIQUATED DRAINAGE SYSTEMS (REC DITCH TEMBLADERO). THE RECOMMENDATION THAT RESULTED FROM THE STUDY WAS TO CONSTRUCT A 13 MILE CONCRETE DRAINAGE CHANNEL FROM SALINAS TO MOSS LANDING HARBOR. THIS RECOMMENDATION CATALYZED A MULTI STAKEHOLDER PROCESS (CASSAGRANDE AND WATSON 2005) TO AVOID CONCRETE CHANNELIZATION AND IDENTIFY ALTERNATIVE WATERSHED MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES THAT COULD REDUCE FLOODING WHILE IMPROVING OTHER WATER RESOURCE GOALS. IN 2008, STAKEHOLDERS ESTABLISHED THE GREATER MONTEREY COUNTY INTEGRATED REGIONAL WATER MANAGEMENT (IRWM) PROGRAM, AIMED AT DEVELOPING MULTI BENEFIT WATER RESOURCE PROJECTS APPROPRIATE FOR STATE WATER BOND FUNDING. IN 2019, THE IRWM PROGRAM DEVELOPED THE STORM WATER RESOURCE PLAN FOR THE GREATER MONTEREY COUNTY IRWM REGION THAT IDENTIFIED A NUMBER OF PROJECTS AIMED AT IMPROVING FIVE WATER RESOURCE ENHANCEMENT GOALS  WATER QUALITY, FLOOD PROTECTION, WATER REUSE, AQUATIC HABITAT, COMMUNITY BENEFIT. ONE OF THE TOP RANKED PROJECTS WITHIN THAT PLAN IS THE CASTROVILLE TO THE COAST  MULTI BENEFIT DRAINAGE ENHANCEMENT PROJECT (THE PROJECT). THE PROJECT AIMS TO PROVIDE FLOOD ATTENUATION, SEA LEVEL RISE RESILIENCY, WATER QUALITY IMPROVEMENT, AQUATIC HABITAT RESTORATION, AND RECREATION OPPORTUNITIES WHICH ALIGN WITH AND SUPPORT THE GOALS OF THE NCWC GRANT PROGRAM.THE ENVIRONMENTAL OBJECTIVES FOR THIS PROJECT IN ITS ENTIRETY ARE TO ACQUIRE AND RESTORE LINEAR SEGMENTS OF FLOOD PRONE FARM LANDS ALONG THE RECLAMATION DITCH TEMBLADERO SLOUGH TOTALING 40 ACRES (FIGURE 2) IN ORDER TO 1) RECREATE FLOODPLAIN HABITAT WHICH WILL INCREASE FLOOD RESILIENCY AND REDUCE STREAMBANK EROSION  2) INTEGRATE OFF CHANNEL WETLANDS TO FILTER WATER WITHIN THE GABILAN WATERSHED DRAINAGE (FIGURE 1) AND REDUCE SEDIMENT AND NUTRIENT CONCENTRATIONS FROM ADJACENT FARMS  3) RESTORE WETLAND HABITAT ON THE FLOODPLAIN AND IN THE CHANNEL TO SUPPORT BIRD POPULATIONS AND FISH SPECIES (STEELHEAD AND TIDEWATER GOBY)  4) INTEGRATE FLOODPLAIN ENHANCEMENT WITH IN PROGRESS DEVELOPMENT OF HABITAT CONSERVATION PLAN FOR THE SALINAS RIVER LAGOON TO ENHANCE CONNECTIVITY AMONG THE FRAGMENTED RIVER (SALINAS LAGOON) AND ESTUARINE (ELKHORN AND MORO COJO MPAS) ECOSYSTEMS  AND 5) PROVIDE RECREATIONAL COASTAL ACCESS TO THE UNDERSERVED COMMUNITY OF CASTROVILLE.

THE MAINE DEPARTMENT OF INLAND FISHERIES AND  WILDLIFE (MDIFW) IS REQUESTING  1,000,000 FROM THE NATIONAL COASTAL WETLANDS CONSERVATION GRANT PROGRAM TO ACQUIRE FEE TITLE TO THE 216 ACRE JORDAN RIVER COASTAL CONSERVATION (JRCC) PROPERTY IN TRENTON, MAINE. THE JRCC PROPERTY WILL BE OWNED AND MANAGED BY SUBRECIPIENT FRENCHMAN BAY CONSERVANCY (FBC).THE JRCC PROJECT IS AN OPPORTUNITY TO CONSERVE THE LARGEST UNPROTECTED COASTAL PROPERTY IN BOTH THE TOWN OF TRENTON AND ON NEIGHBORING MT. DESERT ISLAND, HOME TO ACADIA NATIONAL PARK. THE PROJECT SITE IS A 216 ACRE PORTION OF A LARGER PARENT PARCEL TO BE ACQUIRED BY FBC. THE PROPERTY INCLUDES 74.9 ACRES OF INTERTIDAL WETLANDS ALONG 10,733 FEET OF SALTWATER SHORE FRONTAGE ON JORDAN RIVER AS WELL AS 44.1 ACRES OF FRESHWATER WETLANDS AND 97 ACRES OF SURROUNDING UPLANDS. A CORE STRENGTH OF THE PROJECT IS ITS OUTSTANDING WETLAND VALUES AND IMPORTANCE AS A MARSH MIGRATION SITE. CURRENTLY, THERE ARE 9.5 ACRES OF SALT MARSH ON THE PROPERTY, WHICH FRINGES THE ENTIRE JORDAN RIVER FRONTAGE. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO PROVIDE COASTAL MIGRATION SPACE FOR EXPANSION TO OVER 34 SALT MARSH ACRES UNDER A 6.1 FOOT SEA LEVEL RISE SCENARIO, ACCORDING TO MODELING BY THE MAINE GEOLOGICAL SURVEY. CONSERVING UPLANDS WHERE FUTURE SALT MARSH WILL MIGRATE WILL PREVENT DEVELOPMENT AND SHORELINE HARDENING AND PROVIDE FUTURE HABITAT FOR MARSH DEPENDENT SPECIES. FBC WILL CONSIDER HABITAT RESTORATION OPPORTUNITIES AS PART OF ITS LONG TERM MANAGEMENT, INCLUDING REMOVING UNDERSIZED CULVERTS AND POTENTIAL BARRIERS TO MARSH MIGRATION.WETLANDS ON THE PROPERTY PROVIDE HIGH VALUE ECOLOGICAL FUNCTIONS, INCLUDING MITIGATING FLOODS, STABILIZING SHORELINES AND PREVENTING NUTRIENT LOADING INTO THE JORDAN RIVER. JRCC HABITATS BENEFIT NUMEROUS FISH AND WILDLIFE THAT ARE STATE, REGIONAL, NATIONAL OR CONTINENTAL CONSERVATION PRIORITIES, INCLUDING ENDANGERED AND THREATENED SPECIES, DIADROMOUS FISH AND DOZENS OF COASTAL DEPENDENT AND MIGRATORY BIRDS THAT HAVE BEEN DOCUMENTED ON OR NEAR THE PROJECT SITE. THE JORDAN RIVER IS IN AN ATLANTIC COAST JOINT VENTURE WATERFOWL FOCUS AREA, AN AUDUBON IMPORTANT BIRD AREA, AND CONTAINS EXTENSIVE HIGH VALUE HABITATS FOR WADING BIRDS AND WATERFOWL IDENTIFIED BY THE STATE OF MAINE.THE PROPERTY WAS OPERATED AS THE BAR HARBOR GOLF COURSE FROM 1964 TO 2018. WITHOUT PROTECTION, THE JORDAN RIVER PROPERTY WILL ALMOST CERTAINLY BECOME THE SITE OF RESIDENTIAL OR COMMERCIAL DEVELOPMENT THAT WILL HAVE A LASTING NEGATIVE IMPACT ON THIS COASTAL WETLANDS ECOSYSTEM. THE PROPERTY WAS FIRST LISTED FOR SALE IN 2019, AND AFTER NEARLY SELLING IN THE FALL OF 2021, THE PROPERTY IS AGAIN ON THE MARKET. FBC HAS REACHED AGREEMENT WITH THE CURRENT OWNERS ON A PURCHASE PRICE, AND THERE IS NOW A SECOND CHANCE TO CONSERVE THIS EXTREMELY UNIQUE PROPERTY TO SUPPORT WETLAND DEPENDENT WILDLIFE AND BENEFIT FUTURE GENERATIONS OF PEOPLE. SECURING NATIONAL COASTAL WETLANDS CONSERVATION GRANT PROGRAM FUNDING IS VITAL TO THE SUCCESS OF THIS EFFORT.THE JRCC PROPERTY WILL BE OPEN TO THE PUBLIC FOR LOW IMPACT RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES CAREFULLY BALANCED WITH PROTECTION OF NATIVE HABITAT AND WILDLIFE. FOOT ACCESS TO PRODUCTIVE INTERTIDAL SHELLFISH BEDS FOR LOCAL HARVESTERS WILL BE ENSURED. LIMITED WALKING TRAILS WILL BE SITED AWAY FROM SENSITIVE HABITAT AND LEASHES WILL BE REQUIRED FOR DOGS TO PREVENT WILDLIFE DISTURBANCE. RECREATION WILL GO HAND IN HAND WITH OUTDOOR EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMING. FBC INTENDS TO USE THE JORDAN RIVER PROPERTY AS AN OUTDOOR CLASSROOM BY EXPANDING ITS EXISTING PARTNERSHIP WITH MAINE OUTDOOR SCHOOL TO PROVIDE STANDARDS ALIGNED OUTDOOR EDUCATION FOR 5TH GRADERS IN ALL TEN SCHOOLS IN THE FBC SERVICE AREA.A WESTERLY PORTION OF THE PARENT PROPERTY CONTAINING THE FORMER GOLF COURSE CLUBHOUSE IS EXCLUDED FROM THIS PROPOSAL. FBC WILL CONVEY THE CLUBHOUSE AND SURROUNDING ACREAGE TO HOSPICE NON PROFIT WINGS OF EDEN SUBJECT TO A CONSERVATION EASEMENT. THE CLUBHOUSE SITE WILL BECOME THE SITE OF A NEWLY CONSTRUCTED HOSPICE HOUSE.
POTTER MARSH WATERSHED CONSERVATION PROJECT PHASE II

ILIO POINT, ON NORTHWESTERN MOST POINT OF THE HAWAIIAN ISLAND OF MOLOKAI, CONTAINS UNIQUE COASTAL AND MARINE WETLAND ECOSYSTEMS, AND NATIVE AND ENDANGERED SPECIES THAT ARE THREATENED BY IMPACTS FROM FERAL PREDATORS, INVASIVE PLANTS, AND EXPLODING POPULATIONS OF DEER. IN FACT, AN EMERGENCY PROCLAMATION DUE TO THE DEER OVERPOPULATION HAS BEEN ISSUED BY THE GOVERNOR FOR THE SECOND CONSECUTIVE YEAR FOR  THIS ISLAND. THE RESERVE CONTAINS BIODIVERSE SAND DUNES THAT HISTORICALLY HAVE BEEN IMPORTANT SEABIRD NESTING AREAS, BUT REMAINING NATIVE PLANTS ARE BEING BROWSED TO THE GROUND, AND SEABIRD NESTS ARE BEING CRUSHED BY DEER OR PREYED UPON BY CATS. INTERTIDAL AREAS IN THE RESERVE ARE IMPORTANT RESTING AND PUPPING AREAS FOR CRITICALLY ENDANGERED HAWAIIAN MONK SEALS (MONACHUS SCHAUINSLANDI), AND USED BY GREEN SEA TURTLES (CHELONIA MYDAS) FOR HAULING AND RESTING. LARGE PREDATORS SUCH AS CATS AND DOGS DISTURB THESE ANIMALS AND SPREAD LETHAL DISEASES SUCH AS TOXOPLASMOSIS. IN ADJACENT AREAS, PREDATOR PROOF FENCES ARE BEING CONSTRUCTED TO COMBAT THESE THREATS. THE SUCCESS OF THESE OTHER RESTORATION AREAS OF NORTHWESTERN MOLOKAI HAS DEMONSTRATED THE ABILITY FOR THE WINDSWEPT COASTAL NATIVE VEGETATION TO RECOVER AND ATTRACT SEABIRD NESTING COLONIES. THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO CONSTRUCT A FENCE AT ILIO THAT WILL PROTECT THIS AREA FROM DEER AND LARGE PREDATORS. ILIO IS STRATEGICALLY IMPORTANT DUE TO ITS TOPOGRAPHY THAT IS CONDUCIVE TO FENCING, PRESENCE OF ENDANGERED SPECIES, AND LARGE EXPANSES OF RARE COASTAL SAND DUNES. ILIO WILL BE A KEY ADDITION TO A NETWORK OF COASTAL RESTORATION SITES, AND STRENGTHEN THE ENTIRE NETWORK BY CREATING A LARGER, MORE DEFENSIBLE, PROTECTED AREA THAT CAN ATTRACT MORE SEABIRDS, AND SERVE AS ANOTHER OUTPLANTING SITE. MATCHING FUNDS WILL BE PROVIDED TO PROTECT THE NEARBY MOOMOMI PRESERVE, THE OTHER LARGE EXPANSE OF COASTAL SAND DUNES IN THIS REGION AND A SITE WHERE AN EXISTING FENCE IS DEMONSTRATING RESTORATION POTENTIAL. THIS PROPOSED ILIO PROJECT WOULD EXPAND A PROMISING COASTAL PARTNERSHIP INCLUDING STATE OWNED ILIO POINT AND THE ADJACENT PRIVATELY OWNED PRESERVES. WHILE ILIO HAS LARGELY BEEN NEGLECTED, THAT TREND CAN BE REVERSED BY BUILDING ON THE SUCCESS OF DECADES OF PROTECTION AT THE NEIGHBORING PRESERVES.  OBJECTIVES  EXCLUDE INVASIVE FERAL LARGE PREDATORS (CATS AND DOGS) AND DEER BY CONSTRUCTING A FENCE AND REMOVING THESE ANIMALS IN THE 190 AC FENCE UNIT. THIS WILL RESTORE COASTAL DUNES AND THE INTERTIDAL HABITAT, REDUCE EROSION, AND DECREASE CONTAMINATION OF INTERTIDAL AREAS, CORAL REEFS, AND NEARSHORE WATERS.  MATCHING FUNDS WILL SUPPORT THE PRESERVATION OF THE NEARBY MOOMOMI PRESERVE, INCLUDING FENCE MAINTENANCE, CONTINUED PREDATOR AND DEER REMOVAL, INVASIVE PLANT REMOVAL, AND SEABIRD AND OTHER NATIVE SPECIES MONITORING. ADDITIONALLY, FUNDS WILL INVOLVE AND EDUCATE COMMUNITIES TO INSPIRE APPRECIATION FOR THIS RARE COASTAL ECOSYSTEM.

THE DIVISION OF FORESTRY AND WILDLIFE (DOFAW) PROPOSES THE ACQUISITION OF THE 43.73 ACRE KAHANUI WETLAND IN MOLOKAI, HAWAI'I THROUGH A SUBGRANTTO THE MOLOKAI LAND TRUST (MLT). MOLOKAI S SOUTH SHORE HAS SOME OF THE GREATEST WETLAND RESTORATION POTENTIAL IN HAWAI'I  THE EXPANSIVE COASTALFLOODPLAIN HAS A MOSAIC OF FRESH, BRACKISH AND  SALTWATER HABITATS. SUCH AN UNDEVELOPED FLOODPLAIN IS RARE IN HAWAI'I, LOST MAINLY TO DEVELOPMENT. THIS ACQUISITION IS ESSENTIAL TO PREVENT THE CONTINUED LOSS OF WILDLIFE HABITAT TO INVASIVE SPECIES, SEDIMENTATION AND  POSSIBLY DEVELOPMENT  ATTEMPTS TO SUPPORT THE CURRENT OWNER TO FIND RESTORATION FUNDING HAVE NOT SUCCEEDED. PURCHASE BY ANOTHER OWNER WITH DIFFERENT OBJECTIVES WOULD CONTRIBUTE TOTHE FRAGMENTATION OF THIS FLOODPLAIN (THE SITE IS IN THE CENTER OF THE PLAIN), WHILE A PURCHASE BY MLT WOULD HELP TO REVERSE ONGOING HABITAT LOSSES. MLT ARE COMMITTED TO PROTECTING THE CULTURALLY VALUABLE FISHPOND ON SITE AND  INCLUDING THE COMMUNITY IN RESTORATION EFFORTS  THEY WILL WORK WITH THEMOLOKAI WETLAND PARTNERSHIP AND OTHER LOCAL ORGANIZATIONS TO FACILITATE THIS. ACQUISITION BY MLT EFFECTIVELY RETURNS THE SITE FROM PRIVATE OWNERSHIPTO THE HAWAIIAN PEOPLE. THE LAND IS CURRENTLY ON THE OPEN MARKET, HAS GENERATED INTEREST ALREADY AND  COULD BE PURCHASED FOR NON CONSERVATION REASONS AT ANY TIME, WITH THE LISTING OUTLINING OPTIONS FOR BUILDING DEVELOPMENT. THIS GRANT APPLICATION PROPOSES ACQUISITION ONLY  RESTORATION IS PLANNED FOR FUTURE APPLICATIONS.THE WETLAND, 3 MILES WEST OF KAUNAKAKAI, HAS BEEN DEGRADED THROUGH SEDIMENT FROM PAST UPSLOPE AGRICULTURAL PRACTICES AND  ENCROACHMENT OFINVASIVE VEGETATION (MAINLY MANGROVE). ?0.76 ACRES ARE DRY SCRUBLAND  THE REMAINDER IS NWI DESIGNATED WETLAND. SPRINGS ARE PRESENT AND  AFTERACQUISITION, THERE IS POTENTIAL TO ENHANCE EXISTING FRESHWATER AND  COASTAL HABITAT FOR ENDANGERED WATERBIRDS, MIGRATORY BIRDS, BATS, AND  AQUATIC INSECTS. KAHANUI HAS BEEN IDENTIFIED AS A CANDIDATE IN THE PACIFIC ISLAND CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE CENTER (PICASC) RESTORATION PLANNING PROJECT.FUTURE RESTORATION PLANS (NOT INCLUDED IN CURRENT GRANT FUNDING APPLICATION)RESTORATION WOULD FOCUS PRINCIPALLY ON THE ERADICATION OF HIGHLY INVASIVE RED MANGROVE (RHIZOPHORA MANGLE), PICKLEWEED (BATIS MARITIMA) ANDKIAWE (PROSOPIS PALLIDA). IN FUTURE PHASES, A RESTORATION PLAN WILL BE DEVELOPED AND  IMPLEMENTED TO ACHIEVE THE END GOAL OF A HEALTHY COASTALWETLAND ECOSYSTEM. MLT HAS THE CAPACITY AND  TRACK RECORD TO ELIMINATE INVASIVES AND MANAGE FOR THE RECRUITMENT OF NATIVE FLORA AND  FAUNA. THE SITEHAS DEEP CULTURAL IMPORTANCE, DUE TO A BURIED ?600 YEAR OLD LOKO 'UME'IKI (SHORELINE BOUND FISHPOND). THERE IS POTENTIAL TO STRENGTHEN CULTURAL TIESBY DEVELOPING TARO FIELDS ON SITE  WHEN MANAGED FOR INDIGENOUS AGRO ECOLOGY, THEY PROVIDE EXCELLENT HABITAT FOR WATERBIRDS, AND  SERVE AS A BRIDGELINKING THE LOCAL COMMUNITY WITH CONSERVATION WORK. IN PRELIMINARY OUTREACH SESSIONS, THE COMMUNITY EXPRESSED A STRONG DESIRE FOR THIS APPROACH.FUTURE RESTORATION ALIGNS WITH SIMILAR USFWS FUNDED WORK AT ALAKOKO FISHPOND (KAUA'I) AND HE'EIA NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESERVE NETWORK (O'AHU),INTEGRATING LONG TERM WATERBIRD CONSERVATION WITH TRADITIONAL HAWAIIAN AGRICULTURAL PRACTICES. THE SITE PROVIDES AN OPPORTUNITY TO ADAPT TO CLIMATECHANGE THROUGH MANAGED RETREAT. AS SEA LEVEL RISE (SLR) OCCURS , THERE IS SPACE FOR THE FRESHWATER INTEREST TO RETREAT NORTH. MLT HAS THE IN HOUSECAPACITY TO DEVELOP A CLIMATE CHANGE AND  SEA LEVEL RISE RESPONSE PLAN TO GUIDE THE MANAGEMENT RESPONSE TO SLR.

HAWAII DEPARTMENT OF LAND AND NATURAL RESOURCES, DIVISION OF FORESTRY AND WILDLIFE (DOFAW), IS PROPOSING A TWO YEAR (2023 2025) SHOVEL READYPROJECT TO RESTORE 22 ACRES OF INTERTIDAL ESTUARINE WETLANDS IN THE HULE IA RIVER ESTUARY, LOCATED WITHIN THE NAWILIWILI BAY WATERSHED ON THE ISLAND OFKAUA'I. THE LOWER WATERSHED CONTAINS IMPORTANT ESTUARINE WETLANDS, HABITAT FOR HIGHLY ENDANGERED NATIVE WATERBIRDS, MIGRATORY BIRDS, BATS, ANDAQUATIC SPECIES, AS WELL AS SIGNIFICANT CULTURAL RESOURCES INCLUDING ALAKOKO FISHPOND, A 600 YEAR OLD LOKO I'A KUAPA (BRACKISH WATER FISHPOND).THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON RECREATING THE HYDROLOGICAL AND VEGETATION FUNCTIONS NECESSARY FOR NATIVE BIRDS AND DIADROMOUS AND ESTUARINEFISH TO THRIVE. THIS IS THE SECOND PHASE OF AN OVERARCHING GOAL TO ERADICATE INVASIVE RED MANGROVE (RHIZOPHORA MANGLE) WITHIN THE ENTIRE HULE'IARIVER WATERSHED. IT IS LOCATED ON THE BOUNDARY BETWEEN THE FISHPOND (PHASE I) AND THE HULE IA NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE (NWR), IMMEDIATELYADJACENT TO THE FIRST PHASE AND LEVERAGES THE PREVIOUS WORK DONE UNDER A NATIONAL COASTAL WETLAND CONSERVATION GRANT (NCWCG). THE FIRST PHASESUCCESSFULLY ACCOMPLISHED REMOVAL OF 26 ACRES OF HIGHLY INVASIVE MANGROVE AND ESTABLISHMENT OF 14 ACRES OF NATIVE COASTAL WETLAND VEGETATIONRESULTING IN RESTORED WETLAND FUNCTION AND HABITAT FOR FOUR ENDANGERED WATERBIRDS. THE PROPOSED PROJECT AREA LAND OWNERSHIP COMPRISES 17 ACRESBELONGING TO THE NWR, AND 5 ACRES OWNED BY A COMMUNITY BASED NONPROFIT ORGANIZATION, MALAMA HULE IA (MH).MH, THE SUB RECIPIENT, IF AWARDED, HAS GARNERED OVERWHELMING COMMUNITY SUPPORT WITH MORE THAN 5,000 VOLUNTEERS AND MANY CONSERVATIONAGENCIES CONTRIBUTING TO THE SUCCESSFUL RESTORATION AT THE ADJACENT FISHPOND. PHASE I WAS COMPLETED IN 2021 ACCOMPLISHING ALL GOALS IN A TIMELYMANNER. THIS PROJECT (PHASE II) WILL CONTINUE THE EFFORTS TO RESTORE NATIVE HABITATS TO SUPPORT A HEALTHY AND THRIVING COASTAL WETLAND ECOSYSTEM.BECAUSE OF THE COMMUNITY, LOCAL, STATE AND FEDERAL PARTNER SUPPORT, MALAMA HULE IA WAS ABLE TO PURCHASE THE FISHPOND PROPERTY IN 2021 FORPRESERVATION IN PERPETUITY. THE NWR HAS ISSUED A SPECIAL USE PERMIT TO MH TO CONTINUE RESTORATION AND STEWARDSHIP EFFORTS ON THEIR PROPERTY. MHHAS THE CAPACITY, RECORD, AND DESIRE TO COMMIT TO LONG TERM ECOSYSTEM MANAGEMENT, INCLUDING MONITORING AND MAINTENANCE OF THE SITE TO ELIMINATETHE INVASIVE SPECIES AND PROMOTE THE SUCCESSFUL RECRUITMENT OF NATIVE SPECIES FOR BOTH PHASE I AND II PROJECT AREAS. TOGETHER PHASE I (38 ) ANDPHASE II (21 ) ACCOMPLISH 59  OF THE OVERARCHING GOAL TO ERADICATE INVASIVE MANGROVE FROM THE ENTIRE WATERSHED AND RESULT IN 36 ACRES OFRESTORED ESTUARINE WETLANDS. DOFAW AND MH ARE ALREADY WORKING ON ANOTHER FUNDING PROPOSAL FOR PHASE THREE, TO ADDRESS THE REMAINING 41 THROUGH A STATEWIDE MANGROVE REMOVAL INITIATIVE.

THE WASHINGTON DEPARTMENT OF ECOLOGY AND WHIDBEY CAMANO LAND TRUST ARE PARTNERING ON THIS PROJECT TO PERMANENTLY PROTECT 210 ACRES OF SHORELINE, FOREST, WETLANDS, AND FIELD HABITAT LONG ADMIRALTY INLET ON WHIDBEY ISLAND. THE PROJECT WILL PROTECT 3,500 FEET OF SHORELINE AND TIDELANDS, ASSOCIATED FEEDER BLUFFS, KELP AND EELGRASS BEDS, 50 ACRES OF RIPARIAN AREA AND OPEN FIELD HABITAT, AND 160 ACRES OF COASTAL FOREST. THE PROPERTY ENCOMPASSES A CRITICAL NEARSHORE SALMON MIGRATION CORRIDOR ALONG ADMIRALTY BAY FOR PUGET SOUND SALMON INCLUDING ENDANGERED CHINOOK AND THREATENED HOOD CANAL SUMMER CHUM, AND ESA STEELHEAD SPECIES IN ADDITION TO HABITAT FOR PROTECTED ROCKFISH SPECIES, AS WELL AS NUMEROUS BIRDS AND OTHER WILDLIFE.

THE PROJECT, BY THE WASHINGTON STATE DEPARTMENT OF ECOLOGY (WDOE) IN PARTNERSHIP WITH CAPITOL LAND TRUST AS SUBRECIPIENT, IS TO ACQUIRE A CONSERVATION EASEMENT OVER 227.89 ACRES OF MOSTLY UNDEVELOPED MARINE SHORELINE, POCKET ESTUARY, SALT MARSH AND FORESTED HABITAT ON THE STEAMBOAT PENINSULA IN THURSTON COUNTY, WASHINGTON. THE PROPERTY HOSTS 8,500 FEET OF LARGELY UNDEVELOPED, FORESTED, TOTTEN INLET (SOUTH PUGET SOUND) SHORELINE, A 7.8 ACRE POCKET ESTUARY KNOWN LOCALLY AS HUDSON COVE, AND 4,745 FEET OF PERENNIAL AND SEASONAL STREAMS, FOR A TOTAL OF OVER 2.5 MILES OF MARINE AND FRESHWATER SHORELINE. HUDSON COVE PROVIDES IMPORTANT HABITAT FOR JUVENILE CHINOOK, STEELHEAD AND COHO SALMON AS THEY SEEK SHELTERED AREAS IN THEIR TRANSITION TO THE SALTWATER ENVIRONMENT, AS WELL AS SPAWNING HABITAT FOR FORAGE FISH. IN ADDITION TO FEEDER BLUFFS ALONG MUCH OF THE MARINE SHORELINE WITHIN THE PROJECT SITE, HUDSON COVE HOSTS SALT MARSH AND MUD FLAT HABITAT WHICH PROVIDE IMPORTANT NESTING AND FORAGING HABITAT FOR SHOREBIRDS AND WATERFOWL.

THIS PROJECT WILL ACQUIRE AND RESTORE 35 ACRES ALONG TARBOO CREEK S TRIBUTARIES AND WETLANDS AS AN ADDITION TO THE TARBOO WILDLIFE PRESERVE IN JEFFERSON COUNTY, WASHINGTON. THE PROJECT WILL PERMANENTLY PROTECT A DIVERSITY OF WETLANDS, STREAMS, AND MATURE FOREST THAT PROVIDES HABITAT FOR A DIVERSITY OF AT RISK BIRDS AND WILDLIFE. THREE ACRES OF WETLANDS WITH INVASIVE REED CANARY GRASS WILL ALSO BE RESTORED BY NWI AND VOLUNTEERS IN EDUCATIONAL EVENTS. THE PROJECT WILL SAFEGUARD HABITAT AND WATER QUALITY IN DOWNSTREAM TARBOO CREEK AND DABOB BAY FOR AT RISK AQUATIC SPECIES INCLUDING STEELHEAD SALMON (FEDERAL THREATENED), CHINOOK SALMON (FEDERAL THREATENED), COHO SALMON (FEDERAL SPECIES OF CONCERN), COASTAL CUTTHROAD TROUT, AND WESTERN BROOK LAMPREY.

THE WASHINGTON STATE DEPARTMENT OF ECOLOGY (WDOE), IN PARTNERSHIP WITH PACIFIC CONSERVATION DISTRICT, AS SUBRECIPIENT, WILL RESTORE 140 ACRES OF COASTAL WETLAND HABITAT IN PACIFIC COUNTY, WASHINGTON. THE PROJECT WILL PERMANENTLY RESTORE NATIONALLY DECLINING WETLAND HABITAT TYPES BY REMOVING A PAIR OF TIDE GATED CULVERTS AND REPLACING THEM WITH A 100 FOOT BRIDGE TO RESTORE THE FULL TIDAL PRISM AT THE MOUTH OF SMITH CREEK NEAR ITS CONFLUENCE WITH THE LOWER NASELLE RIVER IN WILLAPA BAY. TIDAL CHANNELS WILL BE REESTABLISHED. THE PROJECT WILL INCREASE CONNECTIVITY AND MIGRATORY ACCESS FOR SALMONIDS AND OTHER ESTUARY REARING SPECIES TO FORAGING OPPORTUNITIES WITHIN 140 ACRES OF RESTORED INTERTIDAL HABITAT AND TO 8.7 MILES OF SPAWNING HABITAT UPSTREAM WHICH IS CURRENTLY BLOCKED BY THE TIDE GATES. THE PROJECT EXPANDS UPON PRIOR ACQUISITION PROJECTS FUNDED BY NCWC AND WILL COMPLETE THE LONG INTENDED RESTORATION OF THIS CRITICALLY IMPORTANT ECOSYSTEM.

THE SAMISH BAY COASTAL PROTECTION PROJECT, BY THE WASHINGTON STATE DEPARTMENT OF ECOLOGY (WDOE), IN PARTNERSHIP WITH SKAGIT LAND TRUST (SLT) AS SUBRECIPIENT, IS TO ACQUIRE AND PERMANENTLY PROTECT APPROXIMATELY 128 ACRES AND 7,400 FEET OF MARINE AND TIDAL RIVER COASTLINE ALONG SAMISH BAY IN NORTHERN SKAGIT COUNTY, WA. THE PROPERTY IS SURROUNDED ON THREE SIDES BY SAMISH BAY AND THE TIDALLY INFLUENCED MOUTH OF EDISON SLOUGH, A FRESHWATER RIVER. IT INCLUDES A FRINGE OF ESTUARINE WETLANDS THAT LIE WATERWARD OF A DIKE, ESPECIALLY ALONG THE SLOUGH, AND TIDELANDS EXTEND INTO THE BAY. THE PROPERTY CURRENTLY SUPPORTS ESTUARINE AND FRESHWATER WETLANDS, COASTAL SHORELINE ALONG A SALINITY GRADIENT, AND TIDELANDS. IT HAS APPROXIMATELY 1.4 MILES OF SALTWATER SHORELINE AND 100 ACRES OF NATIONALLY DECLINING WETLANDS. THE PROPERTY WILL BE PROTECTED THROUGH TWO INSTRUMENTS, 1) A CONSERVATION EASEMENT THAT PLACES IMMEDIATE RESTRICTIONS ON THE PROPERTY AND 2) FEE INTEREST IN THE PROPERTY SUBJECT TO A LIFE ESTATE.

THIS PROJECT, BY THE WASHINGTON STATE DEPARTMENT OF ECOLOGY, IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE NATURE CONSERVANCY (TNC) AS SUBRECIPIENT, WILL SUPPORT 115 ACRES OF TIDAL WETLAND RESTORATION AT TNC S PORT SUSAN BAY PRESERVE. THE PRESERVE PROTECTS HABITAT FOR CHINOOK SALMON, BULL TROUT, AND PUGET SOUND STEELHEAD (ALL FEDERALLY THREATENED)  COHO SALMON (SPECIES OF CONCERN)  SHOREBIRDS  WATERFOWL  AND RAPTORS IN A PRIORITY LOCATION FOR SALMON RECOVERY. RESTORATION WILL INVOLVE EXCAVATING NEW OUTLETS TO THE BAY, RIVER DISTRIBUTARY CONNECTIONS, DISTRIBUTARY CHANNELS ACROSS THE SITE, AN INTERIOR BLIND TIDAL NETWORK, AND CREATING MID AND HIGH MARSH ZONE HABITAT MOUNDS. THE PROJECT AIMS TO SIGNIFICANTLY IMPROVE ESTUARINE HABITAT CONNECTIVITY AT A KEY LOCATION, CREATING FUNCTIONAL LINKAGES WITH ADJACENT NCWCG INVESTMENTS. THE STILLAGUAMISH TRIBE OF INDIANS AND THE TULALIP TRIBES INTEND TO RESTORE THE ADJACENT ZIS A BA II SITE (NCWCG FY20) FOR RECOVERY OF CEREMONIAL AND SUBSISTENCE FISHERIES. THE COMBINED RESTORATION WORK OF TNC AND THE TRIBES WILL SIGNIFICANTLY INCREASE VIABLE HABITAT FOR WHIDBEY BASIN SALMON STOCKS AND OTHER SPECIES, AND AUGMENT CLIMATE RESILIENCE.

THE SOUTH CAROLINA CONSERVATION BANK (SC CONSERVATION BANK) AND ITS CONSERVATION PARTNERS REQUEST  1,000,000 FROM THE NATIONAL COASTAL WETLANDS CONSERVATION PROGRAM FOR THE SOUTH CAROLINA FORESTRY COMMISSION (SCFC) TO ADD 2,180 ACRES OF FORESTED LAND ON THE SANTEE RIVER TO THE WEE TEE STATE FOREST BY ACQUIRING THE RMS WADMACON TRACT (PROPERTY). THE PROPERTY IS ALMOST ENTIRELY PALUSTRINE FORESTED WETLAND FLOODPLAIN FROM DAWHOO LAKE AND WADMACON CREEK TO THE SANTEE RIVER, WHICH GENERALLY FORM THE PROPERTY S NORTHERN AND SOUTHERN BOUNDARIES. THE SOUTHERN BOUNDARY IS OVER 2 RIVER MILES ON THE SANTEE THAT DIRECTLY BUILD ON 3,857 ACRES CONSERVED WITH FY21 NCWCG FUNDS AND THE 12,600 ACRE WEE TEE STATE FOREST. THIS PROJECT IS READY TO IMPLEMENT AND INCLUDES BARGAIN SALE DONATED LAND VALUE, CASH REDUCING THE FEDERAL SHARE, AND BROAD PARTNERSHIPS THAT BENEFIT WILDLIFE AND COASTAL WETLAND HABITATS.

SC CONSERVATION BANK WILL SUB AWARD TO CITY OF NORTH CHARLESTON TO BUY AND PROTECT 440 ACRES OF COASTAL WETLAND HABITAT BY END OF 2023. AFTER ACQUISITION, THE PROPERTY WILL BE MANAGED AS A PASSIVE USE PARK FOR THE CITY OF NORTH CHARLESTON. THE SITE HAS HISTORIC SIGNATURES OF RICE CULTURE FROM THE 18TH CENTURY AND MANY OF THE PROPERTY FEATURES MIRROR THE PLANS SHOWN ON SURVEY FROM 1793. THE HISTORIC RICEFIELDS, THE RESERVE POND, THE EMBANKMENTS FROM THE 1700S AND UPLAND BUFFER OF MIXED HARDWOOD PINE, AND OPEN FIELD WITH GRAND LIVE OAKS. LONG TERM OWNERSHIP AND STEWARDSHIP WILL PRESERVE INLAND RICEFIELD WETLANDS AND CYPRESS TUPELO GUM FOREST FOR SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED.
FUNDS UNDER THIS AWARD WILL BE USED TO ACQUIRE IN FEE SIMPLE AND PERMANENTLY PROTECT APPROXIMATELY 3,368 ACRES OF POCOSIN WETLANDS IN PENDER COUNTY, NORTH CAROLINA.

THE NORTH CAROLINA WILDLIFE RESOURCES COMMISSION (NCWRC), IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE CONSERVATION FUND (TCF), IS REQUESTING  1,000,000 IN FUNDING FROM THE NATIONAL COASTAL WETLANDS CONSERVATION GRANTS PROGRAM (NCWCG) TO PURCHASE IN FEE TITLE 5,610 ACRES OF EXCEPTIONAL COASTAL WETLANDS ALONG LONG BAY IN NORTHEASTERN CARTERET COUNTY, NORTH CAROLINA. TCF WILL BE THE SUB GRANTEE AND RECIPIENT OF ANY AWARDED NCWCG FUNDS.THE LONG BAY PROJECT WILL PROTECT A LARGE NETWORK OF COASTAL WETLANDS OF EXCEPTIONAL SIGNIFICANCE AND PRESERVE MILITARY TRAINING CAPACITY IN EASTERN NORTH CAROLINA. TCF PLANS TO (1) ACQUIRE THE 5,610 ACRE PROPERTY, (2) ENCUMBER THE PROPERTY WITH AN EASEMENT IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE UNITED STATES MARINE CORPS, AND (3) CONVEY THE UNDERLYING FEE INTEREST TO NCWRC TO EXPAND THE CARTERET COUNTY GAME LAND THAT WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE IMPROVEMENT OF WATER QUALITY, HABITAT FOR RARE SPECIES, AND THE OUTDOOR RECREATION BASED ECONOMY OF CARTERET COUNTY, NORTH CAROLINA.

THE WASHINGTON STATE DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES (DNR) SEEKS A NATIONAL COASTALWETLAND CONSERVATION PROGRAM GRANT (NCWCG) IN THE AMOUNT OF  1,000,000 TO PROTECT ONEOF THE FEW REMAINING HIGH QUALITY SALT MARSHES IN PUGET SOUND, AN IMPORTANT SHOREBIRDFORAGING AREA, AND SPAWNING HABITAT FOR ONE OF THE MOST PRODUCTIVE NATIVE CHUM SALMONRUNS IN SOUTHERN PUGET SOUND. THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ACQUIRE 215 ACRES ANDRESTORE 230 ACRES OF RIPARIAN, WETLAND, FLOODPLAIN FOREST AND UPLAND HABITAT, AND ENHANCEENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION OPPORTUNITIES IN THE KENNEDY CREEK TOTTEN INLET WATERSHED LOCATEDIN THURSTON AND MASON COUNTIES, WASHINGTON.THE PROPERTIES WILL BE PROTECTED IN PERPETUITY AND MANAGED BY DNR AS PART OF THE 1,400 ACRE KENNEDY CREEK NATURAL AREA. THE NATURAL AREA BOUNDARY INCLUDES THE TERMINUS OFTOTTEN INLET AT OYSTER BAY, TIDAL REACHES OF KENNEDY AND SCHNEIDER CREEKS AND ADJACENT SALTMARSH, TIDE FLATS, UPLANDS AND RIPARIAN FORESTS, AND THE MAJORITY OF THE MAIN STEM CORRIDOR OFKENNEDY CREEK. THE TWO CREEK SYSTEMS (KENNEDY AND SCHNEIDER) PROVIDE ESSENTIALLY THEENTIRE FRESHWATER INPUT TO THE OYSTER BAY ESTUARY SYSTEM, WITH KENNEDY CREEK BEING THEPRIMARY SOURCE.TO DATE, 1,000 ACRES HAVE BEEN ACQUIRED FOR INCLUSION IN THE KENNEDY CREEK NATURAL AREAFROM FEDERAL AND STATE FUNDING SOURCES, INCLUDING PAST NCWCG FUNDING AWARDS. THEPROPERTIES INVOLVED IN THIS PROJECT ARE AMONG THE FEW REMAINING PRIVATE LANDS WITHIN THENATURAL AREA BOUNDARY. THE PROJECT WILL PROTECT HABITAT FOR A DIVERSE ARRAY OF FEDERALLY LISTEDSPECIES AND STATE PRIORITY SPECIES AND HABITATS, INCLUDING WINTER STEELHEAD, FALL CHINOOKSALMON, SHOREBIRDS, MURRELETS, PEREGRINE FALCONS AND PURPLE MARTINS.ADDITIONALLY, THIS PROJECT BUILDS ON THE EXISTING RESEARCH AND EDUCATION OPPORTUNITIES ATKENNEDY CREEK NATURAL AREA. FIVE THOUSAND PEOPLE, INCLUDING 3,500 LOCAL AREA STUDENTS FROM40 DIFFERENT SCHOOLS, VISIT THE KENNEDY CREEK SALMON TRAIL EACH FALL TO LEARN ABOUT SALMON.THE TRAIL OFFERS THE BEST SALMON EDUCATION OPTION FOR SCHOOL CHILDREN IN SOUTHERN PUGETSOUND AND THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT CONSTRUCTION OF INTERPRETIVE SIGNS AND KIOSKS.

THE CALIFORNIA COASTAL CONSERVANCY AND EAST BAY REGIONAL PARK DISTRICT (PARK DISTRICT) WILL USE THESE NATIONAL COASTAL WETLANDS CONSERVATION GRANT FUNDS TO RESTORE 159 ACRES IN THE WESTERN WETLANDS AND PATTERSON SLOUGH NATURAL UNITS, SUBSETS OF A LARGER 207-ACRE PROJECT AT COYOTE HILLS REGIONAL PARK. COYOTE HILLS RESTORATION AND PUBLIC ACCESS PROJECT (PROJECT) IS IN THE EAST SAN FRANCISCO BAY AREA, IN THE CITY OF FREMONT, ALONG PASEO PADRE PARKWAY, IN ALAMEDA COUNTY, CALIFORNIA. THE 159-ACRE SITE IS OWNED AND MANAGED BY THE PARK DISTRICT WHO WILL IMPLEMENT THE PROJECT. THE 29-ACRE WESTERN WETLANDS AND 130-ACRE PATTERSON SLOUGH NATURAL UNIT ARE THE FOCUS OF THIS GRANT-FUNDED PROJECT. THE PROJECT PRESENTS A RARE OPPORTUNITY TO RESTORE COASTAL WETLANDS AND RIPARIAN HABITATS. IN THE PROCESS, THE WORK WILL ADD BIOLOGICAL DIVERSITY TO THE AREA, IMPROVE HABITAT CONNECTIVITY, AND RESTORE SCARCE UPLAND REFUGIA AND WINTERING HABITAT FOR WATERFOWL, SHOREBIRDS, AND SPECIAL STATUS SPECIES. CURRENTLY, LAND COVER AT THE SITE IS PREDOMINANTLY OPEN FIELDS THAT ARE FALLOW AND COVERED BY A MIX OF INVASIVE PLANTS WITH SMALL POCKETS OF NATIVE PLANT COMMUNITIES. THE PROJECT WILL RESTORE AND ENHANCE FRESHWATER AND SEASONAL SALINE WETLANDS AND MIXED RIPARIAN HABITAT. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO ENSURE THE OVERALL RESILIENCE OF REESTABLISHED HABITATS BY MONITORING SOILS, HYDROLOGY, AND SURFACE AND GROUNDWATER CHEMISTRY TO ADAPTIVELY MANAGING THE LAND. THE OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT ARE: BY DECEMBER 2023, DIRECTLY RESTORE AND ENHANCE 14.5 ACRES OF WETLANDS; DIRECTLY RESTORE AND ENHANCE 144.5 ACRES OF GRASSLANDS, OAK SAVANNA, WILLOW SAUSAL AND MIXED RIPARIAN FOREST, COTTONWOOD-WILLOW GROVE; AND INSTALL EDUCATIONAL INTERPRETIVE PANELS THAT FEATURE THE NATIVE HABITAT, CULTURAL SIGNIFICANCE, AND HISTORY OF THE PROJECT SITE. WESTERN WETLANDS UNIT IS A 29-ACRE AREA CONTAINING A LARGE, DEPRESSIONAL WETLAND THAT PONDS WATER DURING THE WINTER RAINY PERIOD AND AREAS THAT ARE SLIGHTLY SALINE AND SODIC (SALT AND SODIUM-AFFECTED). THE PROPOSED PLAN FOR THIS AREA INCLUDES, SURFACE GRADING (~1-2 FEET IN DEPTH), CONVERTING WEEDY AREAS TO NATIVE GRASSLAND PASTURE, WHICH WILL BE GRAZED BY HERDS OF SHEEP AND GOATS OR MOWED FOR FIRE PREVENTION, AND INSTALL IRRIGATION FOR MANAGED/TIMED FLOODING OF DEPRESSIONAL PONDED AREAS IN THE LATE SUMMER AND FALL MONTHS TO PROVIDE A WATER SOURCE FOR WILDLIFE. THE PATTERSON SLOUGH NATURAL UNIT IS THE 130-ACRE AREA AT THE NORTH END OF THE PROJECT SITE. THE SLOUGH IS A RELIC OF A ONCE MORE EXTENSIVE RIPARIAN FOREST AND BRAIDED CHANNEL SYSTEM. RESTORATION AND ENHANCEMENT WILL INCLUDE: TOPSOIL GRADING, SEEDING, PLANTING, SOIL AMENDMENT (COMPOST ADDITION), AND TEMPORARY IRRIGATION; SEVERAL ROUNDS OF VEGETATION MANAGEMENT TO EXHAUST THE TOPSOIL'S INVASIVE SEED BANK' REVEGETATION AND ENHANCEMENT WORK TO ESTABLISH AREAS OF WILLOW SAUSAL OR WILLOW THICKET, MIXED RIPARIAN FOREST, OAKS SAVANNA, SEASONAL WETLANDS, AND NATIVE GRASSLANDS; PLANT APPROXIMATELY 8,000 - 10,000 NATIVE TREES AND SHRUBS; AND REMOVAL OF A DILAPIDATED BUILDING AND THE ASSOCIATED INFRASTRUCTURE. THE EARTHWORK AT THE SITE INCLUDES CREATING SHALLOW DEPRESSIONS TO ESTABLISH SEASONAL WETLANDS-WITH EITHER SHALLOW EXCAVATIONS (~1-2 FEET) BELOW CURRENT GRADES/ELEVATIONS OR IMPORTING CLEAN SOIL TO CAP OVER EXISTING GRADES - TO ESTABLISH A MORE COMPLEX TOPOGRAPHY AND SUPPORT WETLAND CREATION. THE GRASSLAND AND OAK SAVANNA AREAS CONSIDERED TOO DRY FOR RIPARIAN RESTORATION WILL BE MOWED OR GRAZED FOR FIRE MANAGEMENT, WEED CONTROL, AND AGRICULTURE. COYOTE HILLS REGIONAL PARK IS THE ANCESTRAL HOMELAND OF THE OHLONE PEOPLE. THE PARK AND ITS PROGRAMMING PLAY AN IMPORTANT ROLE IN PRESERVING AND ELEVATING THIS CULTURAL HISTORY. PARK STAFF HAVE DEVELOPED SPECIFIC THEMES FOR ALL AGE GROUPS, SUCH AS A CULTURAL IMMERSION PROGRAM, IN WHICH PARK STAFF TEACH LESSONS ABOUT TRADITIONAL OHLONE VILLAGE LIFE USING A RECONSTRUCTED PIT HOUSE, SWEAT HOUSE, AND SHADE STRUCTURE.

THE POTTER MARSH WATERSHED CONSERVATION PROJECT PHASE I WILL PERMANENTLY PROTECT 62.2 ACRES OF THE LARGEST REMAINING UNPROTECTED AND UNDEVELOPED TRACT OF URBAN COASTAL WETLANDS ECOSYSTEM, CONTAINING COASTAL STREAMS AND NATIONALLY DECLINING WETLANDS THAT DIRECTLY PROVIDE IMPORTANT HYDROLOGIC FUNCTION OF THE POTTER MARSH UNIT OF THE REFUGE. PHASE I WILL CONSERVE APPROXIMATELY 21% OF THE TOTAL DESIRED PROJECT ACRES AND PUT IN PLACE THE PARTNERS CRITICAL TO THE SUCCESS OF FUTURE PHASES. THE TOTAL PROJECT, INCLUDING FUTURE PHASES, EXPECTS TO CONSERVE 302.6 ACRES CONTAINING COASTAL WETLANDS. CONSERVING THE PHASE I PARCELS WILL PROTECT FRESHWATER INPUT VITAL TO THE POTTER MARSH ECOSYSTEM. GROUNDWATER AND SURFACE WATER FLOW FROM THE PROJECT PARCELS ARE VITAL FOR WETLAND RECHARGE IN POTTER MARSH. THE PHASE I PROPERTY WILL PROTECT 6,335 LINEAR FEET OF STREAMS DIRECTLY ADJACENT TO POTTER MARSH. STREAMS FLOWING INTO POTTER MARSH PROVIDE SALMON SPAWNING HABITAT AND POTTER MARSH SERVES AS AN IMPORTANT NURSERY AREA FOR JUVENILE ANADROMOUS FISH AS THEY UNDERGO THE PHYSIOLOGICAL TRANSFORMATION TO LIFE IN THE OCEAN. ESTUARIES ARE AREAS OF HIGH PRODUCTIVITY THAT PROVIDE SHALLOW WATER HABITAT WITH COVER THAT ALLOW JUVENILE FISH TO FEED AND GROW WITHOUT THE EXPOSURE TO HIGH VELOCITY TIDAL CURRENTS AND LARGE PREDATORS THEY WILL FACE IN THE DEEPER WATERS OF UPPER COOK INLET AND THE OPEN OCEAN. FRESHWATER SYSTEMS TO WHICH SALMON RETURN ARE CRITICAL TO THE MAINTENANCE OF THEIR POPULATIONS. THOUSANDS OF MIGRATORY BIRDS STOPOVER TO REST AND RECHARGE. MANY COASTAL-DEPENDENT BIRDS NEST IN POTTER MARSH AND USE THE MARSH AND ADJACENT HABITATS FOR FEEDING. CONSERVING THE PROJECT PARCELS WILL BENEFIT THE ENDANGERED COOK INLET BELUGA WHALES BY SUPPORTING ALL FIVE SPECIES OF SALMON FOUND IN ALASKA THAT ARE AN IMPORTANT FOOD SOURCE FOR THE COOK INLET BELUGA WHALES. THE PROJECT WILL ACHIEVE CONSERVATION OBJECTIVES IN THE ANCHORAGE BOWL PARKS, NATURAL RESOURCE, AND RECREATION FACILITY PLAN, THE ANCHORAGE COASTAL WILDLIFE REFUGE MANAGEMENT PLAN, HERITAGE LAND BANK POTTER VALLEY LAND USE PLAN, MUNICIPALITY OF ANCHORAGE HILLSIDE DISTRICT PLAN, AND THE ANCHORAGE 2040 PLAN THAT DESCRIBES PUBLIC SUPPORT FOR CONSERVING THE WETLANDS ON THE SUBJECT PROPERTY TO BENEFIT ANCHORAGE'S WATER QUALITY, FISH AND WILDLIFE HABITAT, RECREATION, AND EDUCATION OPPORTUNITIES. THE PHASE I PROJECT WILL CONSERVE THE NUMBER ONE RANKING WETLAND PARCEL IN GREAT LAND TRUST'S 2010 WETLAND PRIORITIZATION DRAFTED IN PARTNERSHIP WITH U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, U.S. ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS, NOAA, STATE OF ALASKA, AND MUNICIPALITY OF ANCHORAGE. THE PHASE I PROJECT PARCELS WILL PROTECT A WILDLIFE AND HYDROLOGIC CORRIDOR LINKING THE REFUGE WITH CHUGACH STATE PARK AND CREATE A NEW PUBLIC TRAIL NETWORK WITH RECREATIONAL AND EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES CRITICAL FOR ANCHORAGE'S LARGEST CITY.

THE CALIFORNIA COASTAL CONSERVANCY AND HUMBOLDT COUNTY RESOURCE CONSERVATION DISTRICT ARE RECEIVING $806,990 FROM THE NATIONAL COASTAL WETLAND CONSERVATION GRANT PROGRAM TO IMPLEMENT THE MAD RIVER SLOUGH - WADULH LAGOON RESTORATION PROJECT (PROJECT). THE PROJECT IS LOCATED NEAR LANPHERE ROAD IN THE ARCATA BOTTOMS AREA OF HUMBOLDT COUNTY, CALIFORNIA.THE PROJECT CONSISTS OF THE RESTORATION OF 48.6 ACRES OF DIKED, SUBSIDED, AGRICULTURAL WETLAND TO A COMBINATION OF ESTUARINE AND PALUSTRINE WETLAND HABITATS, INCLUDING SALT MARSH, BRACKISH MARSH, MUDFLAT, SUBTIDAL/INTERTIDAL EELGRASS HABITAT, WHILE ENHANCING AND RESTORING EXISTING RIPARIAN FOREST. MOST OF THE CONSTRUCTION WORK IS PLANNED TO OCCUR IN 2023. POST CONSTRUCTION MONITORING, ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT, RIPARIAN PLANTINGS, AND INVASIVE CONTROL ACTIVITIES WILL OCCUR FROM COMPLETION OF CONSTRUCTION THROUGH THE END OF 2026.RESTORATION WILL BE CARRIED OUT BY A) DIKE REMOVAL AND LOWERING, B) LIMITED IMPORTATION OF SEDIMENT TO CREATE SALT MARSH, C) EXCAVATING LOW-LYING AREAS TO EELGRASS ELEVATIONS, D) REMOVAL OF OLD AGRICULTURAL INFRASTRUCTURE, E) EARTHWORK TO PROTECT ADJACENT PROPERTIES AND ACCESS ROAD FROM FLOODING, AND F) INVASIVE SPECIES REMOVAL AND PLANTING OF RIPARIAN SPECIES. THE PROJECT WILL BE CONSTRUCTED ON LAND THAT IS CURRENTLY OWNED BY THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATION (CALTRANS). CALTRANS IS DONATING THE PROPERTY TO THE USFWS HUMBOLDT BAY NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE. THE PARCEL WILL BE ADDED TO THE HUMBOLDT BAY NWR'S WADULH UNIT, WHICH IS LOCATED ON THE NORTHERN END OF THE HUMBOLDT BAY BARRIER SPIT BETWEEN MAD RIVER SLOUGH AND THE PACIFIC OCEAN. THE PROJECT WILL INCREASE BIODIVERSITY, ENHANCE HABITAT FOR ENDANGERED SPECIES SUCH AS SALMON, STEELHEAD, TIDEWATER GOBY, NORTH AMERICAN GREEN STURGEON, BALD EAGLE, AND PEREGRINE FALCON. THE RESTORATION WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE DIVERSITY OF WETLANDS SURROUNDING HUMBOLDT BAY.THE PROJECT WILL ALLEVIATE A FLOODING RISK FROM THE EXISTING DIKE, WHICH IS IN POOR CONDITION AND AT RISK OF IMMINENT FAILURE. WERE THE DIKE TO FAIL, THE AREA WOULD REVERT TO MUDFLAT AND SUBJECT ADJACENT PROPERTIES AND ACCESS ROADS TO TIDAL FLOODING. THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN THE RESTORATION OF ESTUARINE AND PALUSTRINE HABITATS INCLUDING 3.8 ACRES OF FRESHWATER MARSH, 7.8 ACRES OF RIPARIAN FOREST, 9.8 ACRES OF BRACKISH AND SALT MARSH, 23.7 ACRES OF MUDFLAT, AND 3.5 ACRES OF SUBTIDAL WETLANDS, A PORTION OF WHICH IS EELGRASS HABITAT.THE PROJECT HAS MULTIPLE BENEFITS INCLUDING ECOSYSTEM RESTORATION, RESTORATION OF A BARRIER-FREE LIVING SHORELINE, ENDANGERED FISH HABITAT, HABITAT FOR RAPTORS, RARE PLANT HABITAT, AND OUTDOOR EDUCATION. INFORMATIONAL SIGNAGE, DEVELOPED WITH THE LOCAL WIYOT TRIBE, WILL TELL THE ECOSYSTEM STORY, AND ACKNOWLEDGE FUNDERS. THE PROJECT WILL RESTORE AND ENHANCE WETLANDS AND RIPARIAN FOREST TO PROVIDE NURSERY HABITAT FOR FEDERALLY AND STATE LISTED FISH SPECIES, CANDIDATE SPECIES AND MIGRATORY BIRDS.

THE CALIFORNIA STATE COASTAL CONSERVANCY IS REQUESTING $1,000,000 FROM THE NATIONAL COASTAL WETLANDS CONSERVATION GRANT PROGRAM (NCWC) TO PERMANENTLY PROTECT +/-44 ACRES WITHIN A +/-100-ACRE COASTAL WETLAND COMPLEX THROUGH THE FEE SIMPLE PURCHASE OF BANNING RANCH. THE PROPERTY CONSISTS OF OVER 400 ACRES OF UNDEVELOPED LAND BETWEEN NEWPORT BEACH AND COSTA MESA WITH A BIOLOGICALLY DIVERSE MIX OF COASTAL WETLANDS, RIPARIAN WOODLANDS, COASTAL BLUFF SAGESCRUB, GRASSLAND, VERNAL POOLS, AND RARE SPECIES HABITAT. THE PROJECT OFFERS AN IRREPLACEABLE OPPORTUNITY TO PROTECT IN PERPETUITY 44 ACRES OF COASTAL WETLANDS AND ASSOCIATED UPLANDS ON THE SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA COAST. THE OVERALL PROJECT INVOLVES FEE TITLE PURCHASE OF 384 ACRES TO PREVENT HIGH-DENSITY RESIDENTIAL DEVELOPMENT ON THE PROPERTY, PROTECT ONE OF THE LARGEST UNPROTECTED WETLAND COMPLEXES IN SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA, AND RETAIN THE SITE'S CURRENT ECOLOGICAL FUNCTION. THE OVERALL ACQUISITION WILL OCCUR THROUGH A SINGLE TRANSACTION, BUT A SUBSET OF THE PROPERTY IS DEFINED AS THE NCWC PROJECT ("THE NCWC PROJECT AREA") FOR THE PURPOSES OF THIS PROPOSAL. IT WAS NOT POSSIBLE TO DEFINE THE NCWC PROJECT AREA BASED ON PARCEL BOUNDARIES DUE TO THE SIZE AND VALUE OF THE PARCELS AND NCWC PROJECT COST CONSTRAINTS. THE 44.1-ACRE BANNING RANCH NCWC PROJECT AREA CONSISTS OF A PORTION OF THE OVERALL PROJECT AREA ADJACENT TO THE SANTA ANA (SA) RIVER MARSH AND IS BOUNDED BY ACCESS ROADS. THE NCWC PROJECT AREA CONTAINS 31.4 ACRES OF WETLANDS, OF WHICH 99% ARE NATIONALLY DECLINING TYPES, AND 12.7 ACRES OF UPLANDS. IT HAS HIGH POTENTIAL FOR CONNECTION TO THE SA RIVER MARSH TO FACILITATE TIDAL MARSH RESTORATION. THIS ACQUISITION IS A CRITICAL STEP IN FUTURE RESTORATION OF THE DIVERSE HABITATS ON THE PROPERTY. BANNING RANCH WETLANDS WERE PART OF THE HISTORIC ESTUARY AT THE MOUTH OF THE NEARLY 100-MILE SA RIVER, UNTIL FLOOD CONTROL CHANNELIZATION ALTERED THE LAND'S NATURAL FORM. TODAY, THE ORANGE COUNTY PORTION OF THE SA RIVER FLOWS THROUGH A CONCRETE BOX CULVERT AND FUNCTIONS ONLY AS A FLOOD DRAINAGE CHANNEL. THE REMNANTS OF THE ESTUARY ARE THE HUNTINGTON BEACH WETLANDS, NORTH OF THE SA RIVER AND PROTECTED IN PART BY A 2017 NCWC GRANT, AND THE SANTA ANA WETLANDS, SOUTH OF THE SA RIVER AND INCLUDING THE PROJECT AREA AS THE LAST UNPROTECTED REMNANT. THE SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA WETLANDS RECOVERY PROJECT (SCWRP) SET THE GOAL OF RECONNECTING THESE WETLANDS, UNITING THE SA RIVER ESTUARY FRAGMENTS INTO ONE RESTORATION PLANNING AND MANAGEMENT UNIT. PROTECTION OF BANNING RANCH WILL ENABLE INTEGRATED WETLAND MANAGEMENT, UNDOING THE FRAGMENTATION OF THIS HISTORIC WETLAND SYSTEM.OIL PRODUCTION BEGAN ON BANNING RANCH IN THE 1940S AND CONTINUES WITH 10% OF ESTABLISHED WELLS IN OPERATION. THOUGH THIS LAND USE LED TO HABITAT DISTURBANCE, IT SPARED PROPERTY FROM DEVELOPMENT UNTIL NOW. THE LANDOWNERS INTENDED TO CONSOLIDATE OIL PRODUCTION INTO A 17-ACRE FOOTPRINT AND DEVELOP THE PROPERTY INTO HOUSING, THREATENING THE CONVERSION OF CRITICAL HABITAT. IN 2008, THE LANDOWNERS SUBMITTED PLANS FOR NEWPORT BANNING RANCH (NBR) - A MIXED USE DEVELOPMENT OF 1,375 RESIDENTIAL DWELLING UNITS, 75,000 SQUARE FEET OF COMMERCIAL USES, AND A 75-ROOM RESORT INN. THE LANDOWNERS SUBMITTED A DRAFT ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT REPORT (EIR) FOR NBR IN 2011 AND THE CITY OF NEWPORT BEACH APPROVED THE EIR IN 2012.THE TRUST FOR PUBLIC LAND (TPL), THE MOUNTAINS RECREATION AND CONSERVATION AUTHORITY (MRCA), AND THE BRC HAVE ALIGNED TO SEEK PERMANENT PROTECTION OF BANNING RANCH. TPL AND THE LANDOWNER EXECUTED AN AGREEMENT TO PURCHASE THE PROPERTY BY 6/30/22. MRCA WILL TAKE OWNERSHIP AND MANAGE THE PROPERTY, AND BRC WILL SERVE AS LONG-TERM PARTNER SUPPORTING RESTORATION AND STEWARDSHIP ON THE PROPERTY.
